text:
Hi all,

Would it be useful for there to be a package implementing analytic variational inference? Using, for example, a factorised posterior of a full multivariate normal for model parameters and gamma for precision.
I suppose the use case for this would be very fast and accurate inference for small-ish models, potentially useful for exploratory analysis.

text: me too! numpyro is also very good (and fast), though, I didn’t find the UI as nice as Turing. Both Turing and pyro/numpyro  implement some variation of advi though. Analytic variational inference would not be as flexible as advi but would potentially be faster for some problems.

text:
Hey! Sorry for the ambiguity. By analytic variational inference I meant using an Euler-Lagrange to perform optimisation on a meanfield model with conjugate priors. I *think* this is what Blei et al refer to as coordinate ascent variational inference (CAVI). You could find more details in Matthew Beal’s 2003 thesis.

The approach allows for update equations for optimisation to be derived analytically for conjugate prior models. I have done this in python for a meanfield approximation of MVN on model parameters and gamma on noise precision and it works well for small-medium sized models and is very quick (even in python!). It doesnt do too well for dimensional nonlinear models though.

elements.text: Hey! Sorry for the ambiguity. By analytic variational inference I meant using an Euler-Lagrange to perform optimisation on a meanfield model with conjugate priors. I

The approach allows for update equations for optimisation to be derived analytically for conjugate prior models. I have done this in python for a meanfield approximation of MVN on model parameters and gamma on noise precision and it works well for small-medium sized models and is very quick (even in python!). It doesnt do too well for dimensional nonlinear models though.

text: Yeah. I wouldnt envisage this being an extensive package but one that’s maybe just good for exploration purposes. I.e. just included a handful of models with simple posterior factorisations and for which full conditional update equations are known. A more complicated factorisation where the conditional expectations are more involved would be tedious and probably not worthwhile given that NUTS and ADVI are already very efficient

text:
>  A more complicated factorisation where the conditional expectations are more involved
Well the funny thing about this is that if your conditionals are too entangled, then NUTS will probably also have some issues with your model.
